chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College’s state-based framework but make it track voters more closely by ending winner-take-all and allocating electors proportionally using a uniform method in every state. To protect smaller-state and regional interests without letting gerrymandering decide the presidency, set national guardrails for fair districting (if districts are used), common recount/audit triggers, and clear rules that bind electors to the certified result. Over time, an interstate compact could be used as a backstop if the national popular vote and the electoral outcome diverge, ensuring the winner reflects broad support while preserving federalism.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should keep the state-run structure that values regional and small-state voices, while reducing winner-take-all distortions so more voters feel their ballots matter wherever they live. A strong compromise is to require proportional allocation of electors within each state (or a district-based method only with nonpartisan redistricting guardrails), paired with clear national minimum standards for voter access, ballot counting, audits, and automatic recounts in close races. As an additional backstop if a broad agreement emerges, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact could be used to ensure the overall winner reflects the popular will without an abrupt constitutional overhaul.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform to the Electoral College should make elections feel fair and easy to understand, so that every lawful vote matters while smaller states and rural communities still have a real voice. A workable compromise is to keep state-run elections but end winner-take-all by awarding electors proportionally (with an optional ranked-choice ballot for president), paired with uniform national standards for ballot access, recounts, and risk-limiting audits. Add guardrails against gerrymandering if any district-based system is used, so the rules are hard to game and the winner reflects broad, nationwide support.
